H0.text: Strike-slip fault is the location where convection currents in the mantle cause tectonic plates to diverge.

H1.text: Subduction zone is the location where convection currents in the mantle are thought to be the driving force behind tectonic movement causing the plates to diverge.

H2.text: Mid‑ocean ridges are the locations where convection currents in the mantle cause tectonic plates to diverge.

H3.text: Folded mountains are the locations where convection currents in the mantle cause tectonic plates to diverge.

A4.text: The mantle conveyor due to deep convection contributes to plate motion and the formation of new oceanic crust at mid‑ocean ridges.

A5.text: However, some studies have shown that the upper mantle (asthenosphere) is too plastic (flexible) to generate enough friction to pull the tectonic plate along.

A6.text: Exceedingly large convective cells bring very large quantities of hot asthenospheric material near the surface, and the kinetic energy is thought to be sufficient to break apart the lithosphere.

A7.text: Current research indicates that complex convection within the Earth's mantle allows material to rise to the base of the lithosphere beneath each divergent plate boundary.
